summary.para: Describes a cross timestamp retrieved from a network adapter. A cross timestamp refers to a set of network interface card (NIC) hardware timestamp and system timestamp(s) obtained very close to one another.
To retrieve a cross timestamp, call the function. That function returns the timestamp from the network adapter in the form of an INTERFACE_HARDWARE_CROSSTIMESTAMP object.
For more info, and code examples, see Packet timestamping.
The network adapter driver fills this with a system timestamp whose value corresponds to a value returned by (QPC).
SystemTimestamp1 is obtained before HardwareClockTimestamp; while SystemTimestamp2 is taken after HardwareClockTimestamp. The timestamp values are obtained as closely as possible to each other.
The network adapter driver fills this with a value obtained from its network interface card (NIC) hardware clock.
The network adapter driver fills this with a system timestamp whose value corresponds to a value returned by (QPC).
SystemTimestamp1 is obtained before HardwareClockTimestamp; while SystemTimestamp2 is taken after HardwareClockTimestamp. The timestamp values are obtained as closely as possible to each other.
